subject: Re: [junit] Re: Running Multiple Fixtures in junit.swingui.TestRunner
msgSnippet: ... !? If you mean Ah.. but in proper usage each fixture is a different TestCase class... , then I was merely correcting Dave s words. At no time did I cite
messageBody:
Jim Dixon wrote:

> On Thu, 6 Nov 2003, Dave Astels wrote:
>
> [from the JUnit Web site:]
> > > "Tests need to run against the background of a known set of objects.
> > > This set of objects is called a test fixture.
> ...
> > > Pay close attention, class. The set of objects is the fixture. The
> > > fixture is what you set up. This is clear and unambiguous English
> > > from the authors of JUnit.
>
> > > For that matter, if I google I get
> >
> > Of what relavance is this?
>
> JB cited what appeared to be a quotation backing his interpretation of
> the term. He appeared to be claiming that it came from the JUnit Web
> site. I was investigating the claim.

!?

If you mean "Ah.. but in proper usage each fixture is a different
TestCase class...", then I was merely correcting Dave's words. At no
time did I cite the JUnit web site. I did, however, cite the JUnit FAQ,
which incidentally the JUnit web site blesses as official by linking to
it and calling it "The JUnit FAQ". That was a different question,
though: which I believe was "How do I run two test suites together?" The
Original Questioner wrote "fixture" for "test suite" and that is how
this all started.

Now see, had you just asked me to clarify... but no, you ran with your
assumptions and it led you entirely off course. Just ask! Just say, "JB,
I didn't see that on the JUnit web site..." and then I can write "That's
not what I meant..." and this could have been civil.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
